dt: {bc}an optical {dx_def}see {dxt|optical||2a}{/dx_def} effect that is sometimes seen at sea, in the desert, or over a hot pavement, that may have the appearance of a pool of water or a mirror in which distant objects are seen inverted, and that is caused by the bending or reflection of rays of light by a layer of heated air of varying density

dt.t: A peaceful solution proved to be a {wi}mirage{/wi}.

pt: {sc}delusion{/sc} {sc}illusion{/sc} {sc}hallucination{/sc} {sc}mirage{/sc} mean something that is believed to be true or real but that is actually false or unreal. {sc}delusion{/sc} implies an inability to distinguish between what is real and what only seems to be real, often as the result of a disordered state of mind.
{sc}illusion{/sc} implies a false ascribing of reality based on what one sees or imagines.
{sc}hallucination{/sc} implies impressions that are the product of disordered senses, as because of mental illness or drugs.
{sc}mirage{/sc} in its extended sense applies to an illusory vision, dream, hope, or aim.

pt.t: claimed a balanced budget is a {it}mirage{/it}

et: borrowed from French, from {it}mirer{/it} "to look at, gaze at" (going back to Old French, going back to Latin {it}mīrārī{/it} "to be surprised, look with wonder at") + {it}-age{/it} {et_link|-age|-age} {ma}{mat|admire|}{/ma}
shortdef: an optical effect that is sometimes seen at sea, in the desert, or over a hot pavement, that may have the appearance of a pool of water or a mirror in which distant objects are seen inverted, and that is caused by the bending or reflection of rays of light by a layer of heated air of varying density
something illusory and unattainable like a mirage
